M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, which authorize the Probate and Family Court to modify prior custody orders when a material change in circumstances has occurred and a modification would serve the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, which authorize the Probate and Family Court to modify prior custody orders when a material change in circumstances has occurred and a modification would serve the best interests of the child.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The controlling standard, as articulated in Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981), and reaffirmed in Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), requires the Court to ascertain both change in circumstance and the best interests of the child.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: Schuler is a modification-of-alimony/child-support case, not a custody case, and it articulates the standard for modifying support orders, focusing on a material change in circumstances and ability to pay. While the opinion notes that a child support order may be modified as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children require, it does not set out or analyze a two-part ‘change in circumstance and best interests of the child’ test as its controlling standard. The claimed proposition blends Schuler with Custody of Vaughn and overstates what Schuler itself holds.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28… The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The controlling standard, as articulated in Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981), and reaffirmed in Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), requires the Court to ascertain both change in circumstance and the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The excerpted portion of Custody of Vaughn deals with required findings regarding domestic violence and its impact on the child in a custody determination, not with the Schuler v. Schuler ‘material change in circumstances plus best interests’ standard (which governs modification of prior custody or support orders). The opinion segment provided does not discuss change of circumstances at all; it focuses on the best‑interests analysis and the need for explicit findings about domestic violence. Thus, as presented, Vaughn reaffirms the centrality of best interests and domestic violence considerations, but not the conjunctive “change in circumstance and best interests” standard attributed to Schuler.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that improvements in a parent’s stability, living arrangements, and ability to meet a child’s needs may constitute a material change warranting modification.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct-appeal custody and property-division case; it does not involve a post-judgment modification or discuss what constitutes a ‘material change’ in circumstances. The court evaluates the original custody award under the best-interests standard, not whether later improvements in a parent’s stability, living arrangements, or caregiving ability justify modifying an existing order. Thus, it provides no authority for the proposition about material change warranting modification.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: In deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare... The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that improvements in a parent’s stability, living arrangements, and ability to meet a child’s needs may constitute a material change warranting modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether there was a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying a change of custody, but it does not hold that improvements in a parent’s stability, living arrangements, or ability to meet a child’s needs constitute such a change. In fact, the court emphasizes that positive changes in the mother’s work schedule and quality of life did not warrant a modification of custody and finds no post‑divorce change sufficient to justify changing custody. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the proposition claimed.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that improvements in a parent’s stability, living arrangements, and ability to meet a child’s needs may constitute a material change warranting modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on the best‑interests standard when parents share joint physical custody. It does not address modification based on a parent’s improved stability, living arrangements, or enhanced ability to meet a child’s needs, nor does it discuss what constitutes a “material change” for modification purposes. The cited ALI passage about relocation as a substantial change in circumstances is descriptive of the Principles, not a Massachusetts holding adopting that rule generally for parental improvements. Therefore, the case does not support the stated proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]...
“(4)... the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ... taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Where the evidence reflects that a prior schedule no longer serves the child’s developmental and emotional needs, the Court may modify custody to ensure continuing promotion of the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case is not about modification of an existing custody judgment based on changed circumstances in the child’s developmental or emotional needs. Instead, it concerns an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and discusses the best‑interests standard, primary caregiver considerations, and the impact of a temporary order. The court explicitly declines to apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification and does not hold that a court may modify custody when a prior schedule no longer serves a child’s developmental and emotional needs.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Where the evidence reflects that a prior schedule no longer serves the child’s developmental and emotional needs, the Court may modify custody to ensure continuing promotion of the child’s best interests.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The case involves a choice between two custodial/adoptive placements and focuses on whether changing the child’s placement (a stable, bonded foster home) is justified by his developmental and emotional needs. The SJC affirms the trial judge’s discretionary authority to alter Hugo’s custodial/adoptive plan despite the stability of the existing placement, because the evidence showed the alternative placement better served his long-term developmental needs and best interests. While framed as an adoption-placement decision rather than a post-judgment “modification,” the reasoning squarely recognizes that courts may change a child’s current custodial arrangement when evidence shows another arrangement better promotes the child’s developmental and emotional welfare.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development. … There are times when the best interests of a child warrant ‘fixing’ his custodial arrangement.”

Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 22 Mass. App.raw_text: Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 22 Mass. App. Ct. 91 (1986)
Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 22 Mass. App.proposition: Courts have also emphasized that the child’s expressed preferences, while not controlling, may inform the best-interest analysis.
Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 22 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness, harm from visitation, and standards of proof in review proceedings under G.L. c. 119, § 26. While it notes the child thought of her mother as destructive and reacted negatively to visits, it does not discuss or treat the child’s expressed custodial or visitation preferences as a factor in the best-interest analysis. The court’s reasoning hinges on clinical evidence of harm and stability, not on a stated preference by the child, so it does not support the specific proposition about considering a child’s preferences.
Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 22 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: The record included powerful evidence that the child thought of her mother as destructive and became depressed and lethargic when visits with her mother impended. The judge’s findings, taken cumulatively, demonstrate “close attention . . . [to] the evidence and that the necessity of removing the child from . . . her [mother] has been persuasively shown.”

Custody of Zanetti, 381 Mass. 46 (1980).proposition: Courts have also emphasized that the child’s expressed preferences, while not controlling, may inform the best-interest analysis.
Custody of Zanetti, 381 Mass. 46 (1980).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about the admissibility and voluntariness of inculpatory statements and whether they were the product of a rational intellect, not a custody or best-interests determination. It does not discuss child custody, the best-interest-of-the-child standard, or a child’s expressed preferences, so it cannot support the cited proposition.
Custody of Zanetti, 381 Mass. 46 (1980).relevant_excerpt:
We have recently reversed several convictions because of error in failure to submit to the jury the issue whether a “confession” was the product of a rational intellect.

Commonwealth v. Cole, 380 Mass. 30, 40 (1980). Commonwealth v. Chung, 378 Mass. 451, 456-459 (1979). Cf. Commonwealth v. Johnston, 373 Mass. 21, 25 (1977) (error to exclude psychiatric testimony). ... We hold that the voluntariness of those statements should have been submitted to the jury on the judge’s own motion.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: In Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), the Supreme Judicial Court reaffirmed that the determination must center on the child’s welfare, not parental convenience or prior assumptions about capacity.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates that custody determinations turn on the child’s best interests and lists child-centered factors such as stability, sibling relationships, and whether a parent undermines the child’s relationship with the other parent. It distinguishes precedent warning that custody should not be used to punish a parent and emphasizes that the judge’s assessment of Rose’s behavior was only insofar as it affected Jill’s welfare, not parental convenience or punishment. This aligns with the proposition that the focus must be on the child’s welfare rather than parental convenience or assumptions.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’. . . . The judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable … and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent…. The case on which Rose relies… is not apt… [custody] proceedings were not a vehicle to punish the mother’s behavior. Here, the judge’s assessment of Rose’s behavior was in the context of determining with which parent it was in Jill’s best interest to live.”
